name: Baku
fun_fact: Fun fact: Baku sits on the 'Land of Fire' - natural gas seeping from the ground has burned continuously for millennia at Yanar Dag (Burning Mountain), and ancient Zoroastrians built fire temples here because the flames never went out!

hero_dishes.name: Plov (Pilaf)
hero_dishes.description: Saffron rice with lamb, dried fruits, and chestnuts - Azerbaijan's national dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: At least 40 varieties exist in Azerbaijan. Baku's version often includes lamb, saffron, and caramelized onions. UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage
hero_dishes.where_to_find: ÅžirvanÅŸah Muzey Restoran, Firuze, traditional restaurants in Old City

hero_dishes.name: Kebab (Kabab)
hero_dishes.description: Grilled lamb or beef skewers, often minced (lula kebab) or cubed
hero_dishes.origin_story: Azerbaijan claims the world's best kebabs, cooked over charcoal mangal grills. Sumac and raw onions essential
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mangal Steak House, Dolma, restaurants throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Dolma
hero_dishes.description: Grape leaves or vegetables stuffed with spiced lamb and rice
hero_dishes.origin_story: Azerbaijanis claim dolma originated here - the word comes from Turkish 'dolmak' (to fill). Also UNESCO listed

signature_drinks.name: Azerbaijani Tea
signature_drinks.description: Black tea served in pear-shaped armudu glasses with sugar cubes and jam
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: All day, every day. Tea is sipped through a sugar cube held in the mouth. Armudu glasses keep tea hot at bottom, cool at top

signature_drinks.name: Sherbet
signature_drinks.description: Sweet fruit drinks made from pomegranate, cherry, or other fruits
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Cold and refreshing, especially in summer
